#Text=CHAPTER VI
#Text=The fourth day it happened that the deaf-mute paid his accustomed visit , after which Prince Dolor 's spirits rose .

#Text=They always did when he got the new books which , just to relieve his conscience , the King of Nomansland regularly sent to his nephew ; with many new toys also , though the latter were disregarded now .
#Text=“ Toys , indeed !

#Text=when I 'm a big boy , ” said the Prince , with disdain , and would scarcely condescend to mount a rocking-horse which had come , somehow or other , -- I ca n't be expected to explain things very exactly , -- packed on the back of the other , the great black horse , which stood and fed contentedly at the bottom of the tower .
#Text=Prince Dolor leaned over and looked at it , and thought how grand it must be to get upon its back -- this grand live steed -- and ride away , like the pictures of knights .
#Text=“ Suppose
#Text=I was a knight , ” he said to himself ; “ then I should be obliged to ride out and see the world . ”
#Text=But he kept all these thoughts to himself , and just sat still , devouring his new books till he had come to the end of them all .

#Text=It was a repast not unlike the Barmecide 's feast which you read of in the “ Arabian Nights , ” which consisted of very elegant but empty dishes , or that supper of Sancho Panza in “ Don Quixote , ” where , the minute the smoking dishes came on the table , the physician waved his hand and they were all taken away .
#Text=Thus almost all the ordinary delights of boy-life had been taken away from , or rather never given to this poor little prince .

#Text=“ I wonder , ” he would sometimes think -- “I wonder what it feels like to be on the back of a horse , galloping away , or holding the reins in a carriage , and tearing across the country , or jumping a ditch , or running a race , such as I read of or see in pictures .
#Text=What a lot of things there are that I should like to do !
#Text=But first I should like to go and see the world .
#Text=I 'll try . ”
#Text=Apparently it was his godmother 's plan always to let him try , and try hard , before he gained anything .

#Text=This day the knots that tied up his traveling-cloak were more than usually troublesome , and he was a full half-hour before he got out into the open air , and found himself floating merrily over the top of the tower .

#Text=Hitherto , in all his journeys , he had never let himself go out of sight of home , for the dreary building , after all , was home -- he remembered no other ; but now he felt sick of the very look of his tower , with its round smooth walls and level battlements .
#Text=“ Off we go ! ” cried he , when the cloak stirred itself with a slight , slow motion , as if waiting his orders .
#Text=“ Anywhere anywhere , so that I am away from here , and out into the world . ”
#Text=As he spoke , the cloak , as if seized suddenly with a new idea , bounded forward and went skimming through the air , faster than the very fastest railway train .
#Text=“ Gee-up ! gee-up ! ” cried Prince Dolor in great excitement .
#Text=“ This is as good as riding a race . ”

#Text=And he patted the cloak as if it had been a horse -- that is , in the way he supposed horses ought to be patted -- and tossed his head back to meet the fresh breeze , and pulled his coat collar up and his hat down as he felt the wind grow keener and colder -- colder than anything he had ever known .
#Text=“ What does it matter , though ? ” said he .
#Text=“ I 'm a boy , and boys ought not to mind anything . ”
#Text=Still , for all his good-will , by and by , he began to shiver exceedingly ; also , he had come away without his dinner , and he grew frightfully hungry .
#Text=And to add to everything , the sunshiny day changed into rain , and being high up , in the very midst of the clouds , he got soaked through and through in a very few minutes .
#Text=“ Shall I turn back ? ” meditated he .
#Text=“ Suppose I say ' Abracadabra ? ' ”
#Text=Here he stopped , for already the cloak gave an obedient lurch , as if it were expecting to be sent home immediately .
#Text=“ No -- I can't -- I ca n't go back !
#Text=I must go forward and see the world .
#Text=But oh ! if I had but the shabbiest old rug to shelter me from the rain , or the driest morsel of bread and cheese , just to keep me from starving !
#Text=Still , I do n't much mind ; I 'm a prince , and ought to be able to stand anything .
#Text=Hold on , cloak , we 'll make the best of it . ”

#Text=It was a most curious circumstance , but no sooner had he said this than he felt stealing over his knees something warm and soft ; in fact , a most beautiful bearskin , which folded itself round him quite naturally , and cuddled him up as closely as if he had been the cub of the kind old mother-bear that once owned it .

#Text=Then feeling in his pocket , which suddenly stuck out in a marvelous way , he found , not exactly bread and cheese , nor even sandwiches , but a packet of the most delicious food he had ever tasted .
#Text=It was not meat , nor pudding , but a combination of both , and it served him excellently for both .
#Text=He ate his dinner with the greatest gusto imaginable , till he grew so thirsty he did not know what to do .
